I think there's a little confusion because there are many `MOI` functions:

* [gazebo::physics::Inertial::MOI(Pose)](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/40c062da7dcc0ca6977a420cc7e66cd7a4f9f9eb/gazebo/physics/Inertial.hh?fileviewer=file-view-default#Inertial.hh-213) uses parallel axis theorem as you state above
* [gazebo::physics::Inertial::MOI()](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/40c062da7dcc0ca6977a420cc7e66cd7a4f9f9eb/gazebo/physics/Inertial.hh?fileviewer=file-view-default#Inertial.hh-257) constructs a matrix from the principal and product components, ie. the matrix in the Inertial frame
* [ignition::math::MassMatrix3::MOI()](https://bitbucket.org/ignitionrobotics/ign-math/src/3d32dca333834b57a188c1eec66ec0f82718cb20/include/ignition/math/MassMatrix3.hh?at=default&fileviewer=file-view-default#MassMatrix3.hh-225) construct matrix3 from principal and product components, similar to `gazebo::physics::Inertial::MOI()`
* [ignition::math::Inertial::MOI()](https://bitbucket.org/ignitionrobotics/ign-math/src/3d32dca333834b57a188c1eec66ec0f82718cb20/include/ignition/math/Inertial.hh?fileviewer=file-view-default#Inertial.hh-87) express inertia matrix in base frame (rotation only without parallel axis theorem), which I think it what you are doing in this function

sorry for all the confusion

I think there's a little confusion because there are many MOI functions:

  • gazebo::physics::Inertial::MOI(Pose) uses parallel axis theorem as you state above
  • gazebo::physics::Inertial::MOI() constructs a matrix from the principal and product components, ie. the matrix in the Inertial frame
  • ignition::math::MassMatrix3::MOI() construct matrix3 from principal and product components, similar to gazebo::physics::Inertial::MOI()
  • ignition::math::Inertial::MOI() express inertia matrix in base frame (rotation only without parallel axis theorem), which I think it what you are doing in this function

sorry for all the confusion
